items.text: The FragmentStatePagerAdapter will stop creating new fragments when the current index reaches the number of objects returned by getCount(), so you need to change the method to return a fairly large number that the users are not very likely to reach by continuously swiping in the same direction.
items.href: ViewPager Tutorial: Getting Started in Kotlin | raywenderlich.com

items.text: That way the PagerAdapter will keep creating pages until the page index reaches the value returned by getCount().
items.href: ViewPager Tutorial: Getting Started in Kotlin | raywenderlich.com

items.text: Since getCount() now returns a number larger than the size of the list, the ViewPager will try to access the movie at an index greater than the array size when the user swipes past the last movie.
items.href: ViewPager Tutorial: Getting Started in Kotlin | raywenderlich.com

items.text: Right now the infinite scrolling works only when the user navigates forward through the array (swipes left).
items.href: ViewPager Tutorial: Getting Started in Kotlin | raywenderlich.com

items.text: That is because, when your app starts, the ViewPager displays the movie at index 0.
items.href: ViewPager Tutorial: Getting Started in Kotlin | raywenderlich.com
